Authors:
Shengping Shang, Bo Wang, Song Zhang, Guangli Liu, Xiaofei
Liang, Rong Zhang, Mark L. Gleason, Guangyu Sun
Title:
A novel effector protein CfCE92 of Colletotrichum fructicola
contributes to Glomerella leaf spot virulence by suppressing plant
defenses at the early infection phase
Keywords:
apple, Colletotrichum, effector, pathogenicity, programmed
cell death.
Abstract:
The ascomycete fungus Colletotrichum fructicola causes
diseases on a broad range of plant species. On susceptible cultivars of
apple, it induces severe early defoliation and fruit spots, named
Glomerella leaf spot (GLS), but the mechanisms of pathogenicity have
remained elusive. Phytopathogens exhibit small secreted effector
proteins to advance host infection by manipulating host immune
reactions. Here, we report the identification and characterization of
CfCE92, an effector protein required for GLS virulence. CfCE92 is a
Colletotrichum-specific small secreted protein that suppressed
BAX-triggered cell death in Nicotiana benthamiana. Accumulation of the
gene transcript was barely detectable in conidia or vegetative hyphae,
but was highly up-regulated in appressorium formed during early apple
leaf infection. Gene deletion mutants were not affected in vegetative
growth, appressorium formation, or appressorium-mediated cellophane
penetration. However, the mutants were significantly reduced in
virulence toward both leaf and fruit of apple. Microscopic examination
indicated that infection by the deletion mutants elicited elevated
papillae deposition at the penetration sites, and infection vesicle and
primary hyphae formation were retarded. Signal peptide activity and
subcellular localization assays revealed that CfCE92 localized in both
cytoplasm and nucleus and its cell death-suppressive activity did not
require a signal peptide. RNA-seq and qRT-PCR results confirmed that the
deletion mutants triggered elevated host defense reactions. Taken
together, our results strongly support the interpretation that CfCE92
contributes to C. fructicola virulence as a plant immunity suppressor at
the early infection phase. This study illustrates the functional
importance of effector proteins in GLS virulence.
